title: bubbles friends lockdown sturgeon
story: PEOPLE could meet up in small “bubbles” of friends during the lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon has said.The First Minister of Scotland today suggested the public could decide on one key group of pals who they were allowed to see.Ms Sturgeon told BBC Radio Scotland’s Good Morning Scotland that Britain could follow the countries currently looking at expanding “households” to allow small gatherings of people.She said: “Some countries are starting to look at slightly expanding what people would define as their household – encouraging people who live alone to maybe match up with somebody  who is on their own or a couple of other people to have almost kind of bubbles of people.“And the key thing there is,you’re seeing maybe one or two more people outside your household, it’s got to be the same people on a day-to-day, week-to-week basis so you’re still limiting the ability for the virus to transmit.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.“Now, none of these are fixed decisions yet, but these are all the kind of things we’re trying to work through.”Currently the UK rules state that people should not meet up with anyone they do not live with.It comes one day after the Scottish leader urged the UK Government to treat people like grown ups as she shared her draft plans for ending Scotlands lockdown.The Scottish First Minister yesterday insisted that politicians should be frank with the public - after Government scientists said last night that social distancing could continue until .Her proposed plan for relaxing the lockdown included:Ms Sturgeon stressed the strict measures were still absolutely necessary, but said Scotland needs to chart a way forward to live with the virus over the coming months.

title: general sir nick carter provided a sense of hope why didnt we call in the army earlier
story: I DON’T know about you but I felt greatly reassured this week by the presence of General Sir Nick Carter at a government press briefing.Standing there in unorm, delivering crisp, authoritative information, the Chief of the Defence Staff gave me a sense of real hope.Finally, it was good to see an adult in charge, and for the first time I felt everything really was going to turn out all right in the end.There were no woolly, evasive tactics — instead, just clarity and common sense.Sir Nick, didn’t sugar-coat what we are all facing.He said Covid- was “the single greatest logistic challenge” he had seen in  years of service.He didn’t downplay the scale of the mountain we all still have to climb but his encouraging words stfened our resolve to Keep Calm And Carry On.It was like drinking a cool glass of water and, I swear, I felt the stress oozing out of my body.The Armed Forces have been playing a blinder.They have given invaluable help in setting up the Louisa Jordan Hospital in Glasgow and the new Nightingale hospitals across England, which were kitted out in a matter of weeks.To be honest, I would have brought in the Army a hell of a lot sooner and given them the task of procuring and distributing PPE so we could have avoided the woeful shortages that have seen nurses having to reuse flimsy aprons and even resort to wearing cagoules to protect themselves on the front line.Sir Nick also highlighted the work being done by the Army to counteract  information and scare tactics, especially some of the rubbish online, which is unsettling, isive and utterly irresponsible.With the typical humility that characterises the British Armed Forces, Sir Nick said the men and women under his command were simply there to support the heroic healthcare workers at the sharp end — both in the NHS and social care.He also paid tribute to the man of the moment, World War Two veteran Captain Tom Moore, who has raised more than £million for the NHS.Sir Nick said Tom “embodies the sense of service and duty ingrained in the military”.Indeed he does — and we are seeing examples of that sense of service and duty in all areas of the Armed Forces every single day.You just have to look at Army cadets such as -year-old Chris Johnson, from Warrington, Ches, who has been making PPE visors for NHS staff using his D printer at home.The RAF is flying in crucial protection equipment, and Army reservists are working to create technology that will make PPE delivery more joined-up and efficient.Of course, on top of the Covid- crisis, the Army, Navy and RAF still have their normal operational tasks to carry out.But just like our NHS and the police force, the Armed Forces have been subjected to horrendous budget cuts.These cannot be allowed to continue and must be reversed, even in the extremely tough economic future we all now face.I sincerely hope, when the dust settles and we are back to some kind of normality, that this Government and each one after it will realise the truly vital jobs are those being done by the men and women who work tirelessly to make and keep our lives safe.And that they are rewarded with respect, jobs for le — and stonking pay rises.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.ONE thing that never fails to lt my sprits when I am out for my once-a-day dog walk is the children’s rainbow drawings stuck on the windows and doors of the houses I pass and etched in chalk on paths and pavements.Even the littlest royal, Prince Louis, has been getting in on the act to show his support for our NHS and key workers.The joyful pictures of him with multi-coloured paint all over his hands, taken by proud mum Kate, are the perfect way to mark his second birthday.Along with big brother George and sister Charlotte, Louis is being home-schooled by his mum and dad who, like all parents, will have a new-found respect for teachers.William and Kate have been quietly and effectively doing their bit to help us feel more positive during these tough times.Their video calls to hospitals and schools, plus footage of their children joining in the Thursday night clap for carers, genuinely makes a dference.The Queen must take a lot of solace from her grandson and his near-perfect family.I hope it eases her worries about her husband’s health, the scandal over Andrew and concerns about Harry, who is so very far away.THERE are lots of seriously bad home haircuts at the moment.And I’m afraid I have added to the list after I attacked my long-suffering husband with the electric clippers.Poor Steve ended up like a newly shorn baa-lamb and narrowly avoided having both his ears lopped off.Luckily, he can’t see the back of his head.And, thankfully, hair grows back . . .I HAD to chortle at rumours this week that I am to sign up for the next series of Strictly.This. Will. Never. Happen.I adore the show and am glad it is on track toas usual later this year.But I know I would be very, very bad – and not in a funny Ed Ballsy way.I’d just be embarrassingly woeful. At the age of , I don’t want to be dragged around the dancefloor by the long-suffering Anton du Beck, showing off my knickers like Ann Widdecombe.I reckon the idea I might be involved in Strictly all started because of the ­glorious pro dancer Luba Mushtuk, who was paired with Olympic rower James Cracknell, last year and exited far too soon.We met each other at the Jason Vale health retreat, below, in February, where people go to recharge their batteries.It feels like a letime ago that we were all enjoying long walks, yoga and exercise classes, making new friends along the way.Luba very kindly gave us all a Strictly masterclass. I’ll never forget the hilarious lessons out in the sunshine – with a view of the lakes and hearing everyone’s laughter.Although I really enjoyed myself, it made me realise I could never, ever be a empathy with patients and their families.But it also makes us realise that behind the daily pm briefings are real people just trying to do their best.I’M still baffled by what to do when it comes to wearing a face mask.EvenI could get one, I don’t want to deprive a worker in the NHS, a care home or public transport, as these grafters are the priorities.We are told by some thatwe stay at home, and put extra pressure on the NHS, and figures show we haven’t been going to AE or phoning ambulances unless we’re severely ill, which is laudable.But you can go too far.I would urge anyone who happens upon a lump or something suspicious to get help right away.Cancer specialists report a drastic fall in the number of people seeking help and fear a huge increase in cancer cases.So don’t think you are title: scientists dont agree coronavirus thinking properly
story: SOME scientists tell us we should definitely wear face masks when we are outside while others say they are a complete waste of time. In Sweden, they say that everyone should rub up against one another when shopping, while in France they are ­ordering everyone to stay inside for another three weeks. Some boffins say that testing is the answer to Covid-. Some say it isn’t.Some say  is the age where you most need to worry. Some say it’s .Some say the virus will be wiped out by summer weather. Others say it won’t.And meanwhile, everyone is sitting at home thinking, “Can you lot make up your bloody minds.”But that’s the point of science. There should never be a ­consensus.Everything should constantly move as new discoveries are made. Emc until someone proves that it doesn’t.My colleague Rod Liddle explained last weekend that when the first atom bomb was about to be tested, none of the utterly brilliant men who’d designed it could agree on what would happen.Some said the explosion would be small. Some said it would be massive.One thought it might set the ­atmosphere on fire. One said it wouldn’t work at all.Today, we are told that all of science is agreed on global warming.We hear it IS happening and it IS our fault. No argument is allowed.History has taught us that this is ­dangerous.A hundred years ago, someone came up with a new idea called eugenics.The idea was that the human race was doomed because too many black and ­stupid people were having babies.We can see now that this is lazy, racist nonsense but back then it was a ­dferent story.Boffins at all the most prestigious ­institutions in America were captivated by it.They worked on it at Yale and ­Hard. Millions was spent on research.The greatest minds were taken in, Nobel Prize winners among them.HG Wells supported it and so did George Bernard Shaw and Alexander ­Graham Bell.Legislation was passed to promote it.Winston Churchill believed in it, as did US presidents Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow ­Wilson.So just like global warming, we had an idea backed by leading politicians and many top celebrities.And anyone who said it was stupid was told to shut up.“We have science on our side” they screamed.Yeah, but they also had Hitler on their side.He believed so ­passionately in eugenics, he came up with the Aryan Nation, built concentration camps and murdered six ­million Jews.Be glad then that scientists can’t agree on what to do about Covid-.It shows they are ­thinking. When they say they all agree, it shows they’re not.EVERY European country has dferent ideas about which businesses can re-open next week and which ones cannot.But they’d all really like to give the green light to one thing: Hairdressers.I realise, of course, that everyone has now reverted to their original hair colour and that in Scotland it’s easy to spot the ginger roots of recession.But I just can’t see why this matters so much. And then I saw that picture of Pierce Brosnan . . .TO mark something called Earth Day , Prince Charles has said that in future we should put the “people and the planet” first.Hmmm. Not sure that’s going to work. Because what the planet wants and what people want are two very dferent things.What people want is to be warm and comfortable. We also want to be happy, which means we want a new sofa from DFS, a nice car, a couple of holidays every year and a fridge full of ice-cold beer.Charles would probably argue that the “people” he’s talking about are those who live in mud huts in Africa and Asia and bits of South America.Right. So what do they want  Well, I’m fairly sure thatyou asked them, they’d say they’d like a new sofa, a nice car, a holiday or two and a fridge full of ice-cool beer.That means we must build power stations and roads for them.We must dam their rivers and pull down their jungles to make way for sewerage and water pipes and factories and hospitals and shopping centres.I’m fairly confident then thatwe put people first, the planet is going to feel like we’ve trodden on its toe.I WAS out on my tractor this week, doing a safe and steady mph on a narrow country lane, when I noticed in one of the seven rear view mirrors that behind me, there was a small army of cyclists who couldn’t get past.Ooh, I was happy.I was so happy in fact, that when I got home, I drove right past the drive so that I could keep them all behind me a little bit longer.Payback.It’s so, so sweet.COUNCIL chiefs in Manchester say that the city has been so lovely and quiet these past few weeks that they are thinking of banning cars for ever.Really  You want to stop all those Cheshire boys coming into the city centre on a Friday night with their Ferraris and Bentleys Good luck with that.THIS week, we read about a builder who’d kept his we happy by turning his dumper truck into a luxury bath.He’d even used a drill attachment to create bubbles.Very clever but I knew a man in Doncaster back in the day who made his kids a swimming pool out of a skip.He tilted it so there was a deep end and even put a brazier underneath, so it was fully heated.WHETHER you’re doing a house-party or video conferencing with colleagues, it’s critically important you get the background correct.Tory MPs using Skype to do interviews on the evening news usually put themselves in front of a book case.This tells us they are wise and well read.Celebrities usually make sure there’s a bit of zebra skin in the shot and a pickled shark or two on the wall.This week, my friend Trinny Woodall hosted a live online make-up tutorial from her bathroom.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Doubtless she made sure the background was spick and span. And it was. Right up to the moment when her partner, Charles, , walked into the back of shot. Naked. Stuff like that can happen to anyone who’s not careful.Last week, I hosted an online general knowledge quiz. No one got any of the questions right. They were all too busy staring at the mountain of champagne over my shoulder.Tragically, I’d bought it for the guests at my th birthday party a couple of weeks ago. transport use has ticked up in a way that suggests something more is going on and that has set off alarm bells.“We know it has been hard but everyone needs to stick with it.“The more people comply with the rules, and we slow the spread of this virus, the sooner we can think about easing rules.”But there are signs a UK-wide approach is splintering.Nicola Sturgeon suggested Scots could soon be allowed to meet a small “bubble” of friends or family.And Northern Ireland’s First Minister Arlene Foster said less-affected areas should be allowed to end restrictions sooner.But Wales announced tougher measures.Officials unveiled seven criteria that must be met, two more than the UK-wide plan.It added people must “not leave or remain away” from their homes for longer than absolutely necessary.The Welsh government is also considering a fresh crackdown on second home visits.Ms Foster told the BBC: “We have been working together as four nations, continuing to decide what is the best way forward.“But the two positions are not mutually exclusive.“We may, as a country, decide there are dferent regions that will move at dferent times.”Testing capacity and PPE must be sufficient to be triggered by factors including economic benefits, risk of further infections and how easily the lockdown could resume.N. IRELANDEXIT from lockdown could take a dferent pace from the rest of the UK, says First Minister Arlene Foster.The Northern Ireland executive will look at hospital and intensive care admissions along with numbers of deaths and take into account the state of lockdown measures in the Republic of Ireland.Health Secretary Matt Hancock continued to insist the focus was on stopping the spread of the virus and it was too soon to end lockdown restrictions.But he was comfortable with some businesses reopening.A No source said: “We know there’s only a certain amount of this that the public can take.“That’s why ministers want to make progress as quickly as possible on the five conditions the Government has set out.“By taking the right steps at the right time and going into lockdown when the scientic evidence justied that step, we were able to ensure compliance was at its highest when it mattered.“As a result we have flattened the curve and stopped further spread of the disease.”England’s chief medical officer Chris Whitty played down the prospect of regional iations.But more and more are not.We understand the temptation.We are all stir crazy.The weather has been great.If you have no symptoms, it’s hard to grasp why you can’t be out enjoying it.The Government always feared we would tire of a lockdown just as deaths were still peaking.That’s why they delayed it.Other nations are now relaxing theirs — that may prove disastrous.Home Secretary Priti Patel must get her tone right today.The public will not welcome threats about harsher restrictions.She must treat us like adults.Explain how vital it still is to keep the infection rate down, or deaths will soar again and perhaps swamp the NHS.But the Cabinet must bust a gut to work out how to safely release as many as possible from this house arrest in a fortnight.For now, heed the advice:Stay home, save lives. title: free sunflower seeds giveaway lockdown
story: These magnicent blooms are perfect for bringing some cheer while we are all stuck in our homes and gardens.So today we are giving away FREE seeds so all our readers can grow their very own Sun flowers.It is the perfect time of year to plant them — and they are easy and quick to grow. Kids will love getting involved, too.I have been growing sunflowers with schoolchildren up and down the country for many years and can vouch for their popularity with younger gardeners.They are also brilliant for the environment — boosting the ­numbers of bees, insects and birds we see around us.Be one of the first to grow our very own Sun sunfloweroffered ­exclusively today in our ten-seed packets.Growing up to ft high, they are suitable for balcony pots and patio containers, as well as ­borders or even a low hedge.We already have rainbows celebrating the NHS brightening our windows during lockdown. Now let’s make ­sunflowers shine from every window sill, patio and garden across the land.If you enjoy growing our seeds, there are lots of other ieties you can try, too.The very tall ­sunflowers, such as Kong, Giraffe and Tall Timbers, grow to more than ft high.The intermediates go up to ft and the babies, including our seeds, reach about ft.Above all, they are easy and fun to raise. Just follow my ­simple steps below.Make the most of your garden, patio or balcony while at home with our great helianthus soleil giveaway.Our sunflower soleils are perfect for homes of any size as they are shorter than traditional blooms.They are also easy to grow, so perfect for novice gardeners. To claim your free packet of seeds, go to sunoffers sunflower and follow the simple instructions.Make sure you are quick as there are only , packets available on a first-come, first-served basis.Once you have ordered your free packet of seeds, they will be posted direct to you.sunoffers sunflowerPLACE your seeds half an inch deep into damp soil and they will be spouting ­in a couple of weeks.Sow two or three batches at three to four-week ­intervals to get a continuous stream of flowers.The shorter, quick-growing early kinds will be in flower in  to  days. The big ones will take longer.Or raise the seedlings indoors so the children can watch their progress. To do that, place seeds on a damp kitchen paper towel in a clean container.As soon as you see tiny roots emerge, plant them into small pots or trays of moist ­potting compost.Now they need full light and can go on to a window sill or patio table.Check regularly to see the compost does not dry out.Once they are six or more inches high they can be planted either in final containers or out in the garden.ASK children to draw a flower and they usually sketch out a sunflower – a single stem with yellow petals ­surrounding a dark central disc.Soyou’re aged under , show us your drawing skills and you could win a £ National Garden gt token.Send your colourful drawings or ­paintings to sunflowers@ the-sun by May , , and I will pick my top ten artists, who will each receive a £ token.We will also be giving away another ten vouchers for the best ­photos of your sunflowers when they start flowering this summer.Send those photographs to sunflowers@the-sun by September , .For full TCs here.BY paying attention to your garden, balcony, window sill – or even that unloved patch of ground down the road – you can unlock a host of benefits for yourself, your kids and your community.You can encourage wildle to thrive. Hedges, trees, flowers and even grass are havens for important critters, from birds and hedgehogs to frogs and beetles.You don’t need a sprawling estate to make a dference.One of the best things about sunflowers is their ability to absorb toxins. After the nuclear disasters at Hiroshima, Chernobyl and Fukushima, fields of sunflowers were planted to reduce toxic metals and radiation levels in the soil.They are also perfect for pollinating insects including bees and butterflies. And at the very end of their le they produce enough seeds to feed a flock of birds.There are plenty more simple ways we can help the environment from our gardens, too.Eating more fruit and veg and less meat is something we can all do. Tomatoes, beetroot, courgette and lettuce are easy to grow and can be sown indoors now and put on a sunny window sill to germinate. Use cardboard toilet roll tubes or egg boxes for this.Plant the seeds by following the packet instructions and keep them moist until they are ready to plant outside.Lettuce will grow just as easily indoors or on a balconyyou prick out the smaller seedlings to give the stronger ones more space.If herbs are your thing, include lemon balm. A few leaves steeped in hot water makes a fragrant tea that can help calm anxiety.Plant herbs as near to the kitchen as you can so you can grab a handful when you’re cooking.Plants and flowers provide food for nature but you can also build a home for frogs, ladybirds, beetles and other insects – it’s a great way for kids to see them up close.You don’t need anything fancy. Old bricks, bits of wood, logs, layers of cardboard, twigs, roof tiles or broken terracotta pots piled up in a semi-organised heap will do. The idea is to create lots of tiny, dferent-sized spaces for creatures to crawl into.Just be sure to put something waterproof on top to keep out the rain.You can even create a “hedgehog highway” by cutting a small hole – about the size of a CD – at the base of your fence on both sides of the garden. Encourage your neighbours to do the same, too, as hedgehogs like to roam large distances and this stops them getting penned in.If you haven’t got a garden, growing plants on your balcony or window sill can be just as beneficial for you and for nature.Andyou’re struggling for space there too, when you’re out on your daily exercise take note of unused bits of ground – around the base of street trees, on roadside verges, abandoned empty planters – that might benefit from a bit of colour.Plant your sunflower seeds there and watch them grow as you walk, run or cycle past each day.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meccas grand mosque deserted lockdown
story: The Saudi Arabian mosque attracts more than million Muslims every year during the three weeks of Ramadan.The images show the mosque nearly empty with barriers in place for the small amount of Muslims allowed in to pray during the first day.Workers entered the Kaaba before worshippers arrived to disinfect the area to stop the potential spread of the virus.Across the world, Muslims are unable to pray in mosques due to lockdown measures imposed worldwide.Although countries dfer on the strict nature of those measures, religious gatherings have been banned.Several countries have eased restrictions on the occasion of the holy month with Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and other countries reducing the duration of the lockdowns.The UAE said yesterday it has decided to prayer, isolated or socially separated in mosques.Mosques that are usually brimming with the faithful are closed this Ramadan including in Saudi Arabia, home to Mecca and Medina, the holiest cities in Islam.So far the kingdom has , positive coronavirus cases with more than  deaths.In a statement, Saudi King Salman bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud lamented the necessity to maintain social distancing to halt the spread of the novel coronavirus and the damper it would place on this years celebrations.It pains me to welcome the glorious month of Ramadan under circumstances that forbid us of prayers in global threat of COVID-.The UKs three million Muslims started observing the holy month of Ramadan last night.Ramadan marks the month when the Quran was revealed to Prophet Muhammad by Allah.The holy month will see Muslims around the world fasting during daylight hours for  days.All Muslims who have reached puberty are expected to fast during Ramadan, although there are some exceptions.Women who are menstruating or pregnant and those suffering from illness do not have to fast.The rules mean food and drink, including water, are not allowed during daylight hours for the entire month. The Islamic calendar is based around the lunar cycle, the holy month of Ramadan rotates by approximately ten days each year.The month is confirmed with the sighting of the new moon.Muslims then celebrate with a massive -hour party involving family and friends called the feast of Eid al-Fitr.This celebration is marked with lights, decorations and gts, with worshippers often dressing up and decorating title: diy shoppers flock bq homebase lockdown
story: BQ and Homebase shoppers today flocked to reopened stores as Brits started to venture out during lockdown.Hardware stores have been labelled essential during the coronavirus crisis with BQ reopening half of its stores across the UK.And shoppers today donned protective gear including face masks and gloves as they headed to the hardware stores on the weekend.Long queues of people socially distancing were seen outside BQ in Stoke-on-Trent in Staffordshire, while DIYers headed to another store in Cricklewood in North London.Some were seen buying plants and other hardware while others were seen buying home spas.BQ is limiting the number of customers in the stores at any one time, and has installed screens at checkouts and floor markers to help social distancing.And an Apple Mobility Trends report revealed there has been an  per cent increase in people heading out on foot in the UK in the past four weeks.Matt Hancock this week announced businesses which have re-opened after shutting down over the coronavirus crisis were never required to close.The Health Secretary welcomed the move by firms to get people back to work amid signs Brits are growing tired of the shutdown.Appearing on Sky News, Mr Hancock said companies were never required to shut down - so long as they could operate with adequate social-distancing.He said: The things that are restarting are things that we never required to close in the first place, but what the companies have been doing is working out how they can have safe working following the social distancing rules whilst people are at work.Throughout weve allowed hardware stores to stay open, and the construction industry, but what businesses have been doing is taking the last couple of weeks to work out ok how do you stay open and stay within the social-distancing rules at work So its absolutely fine for those businesses to stay open because they were never required to close by the social-distancing rules.Government officials are still trying to thrash out how such a system would work as plans begin to be drawn up about how to ease the lockdown.Andministers are reportedly looking at easing strict stay at home rules in favour of creating groups of people known as clusters or bubbles.Pictures have emerged this week of growing numbers of people heading outside, with road traffic up  per cent.Britain entered the coronavirus lockdown on March , and some European nations are beginning to ease measures.But authorities have warned some of the restrictions were likely to remain in place for much of the year.Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty warned the only exit from lockdown will be a vaccine or drugs to treat coronavirus.Initially, BQ had offered an online-only service to help protect staff and customers, meaning shoppers could only choose between home delivery and click and collect.However, after monitoring other stores social distancing measures, the hardware chain initially reopened  branches on the weekend of April  .A further  branches reopened on April , with an additional  stores opening on April .This takes the total number of open BQ stores to  - you can find the list of open branches here.These stores are open from am until pm, although times may y between branches.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: ramadan 2020 what time iftar today uk
story: Those taking part in the month-long fast abstain from eating or drinking between dawn and sundown but come together each evening at sunset for a meal called Iftar.Iftar times y across the UK according to sunrise and sunset.Here are the key timings for Maghrib in London throughout Ramadan , Iftar should be eaten after:When should Iftar be eaten where in the UK Muslims must fast between sunrise and sunset every day in Ramadan.However, they are able to enjoy one meal pre-dawn and one after sunset each day.Iftar is the meal eaten after the fourth prayer of the day, the Maghrib, which happens just after sunset.In Arabic, tar means break of a fast, and fatoor means breakfast.It is the second meal of the day during Ramadan as those taking part in the fast must not eat or drink anything during daylight hours.The Suhur is consumed in the morning, and can be as early as .am.The Iftar is considered a blessing, often enjoyed as a community.It is thought not eating during daylight hours, as well as not drinking, smoking or indulging in sex will lead to greater taqwa or consciousness of God.The time of spiritual reflection, improvement and increased devotion and worship is thought to teach followers how to be more self-disciplined and have empathy for those less fortunate.But with lockdown measures in place, gatherings will need to be kept according to government guidelines.This year, Ramadan began on Thursday April  and will end on Saturday May .The fast is  days long and the beginning and end are determined by the lunar Islamic calendar – meaning it depends on when the new moon is sighted.Hilal, the crescent, is usually a day or more after the astronomical new moon.The night of power or night of decree is considered the holiest night of the year, as Muslims believe the first revelation of the Koran was sent down to Muhammad on this night.Its thought to have occurred on an odd-numbered night during the last ten days of Ramadan - the , , ,  or th.The first day of fasting begins on April, ,  and the final tar should take place on the evening of May .The holiday of Eid al-Fitr marks the end of Ramadan and the beginning of the next lunar month.This annual observance is regarded as one of the Five Pillars of Islam.A common greeting is Ramadan Mubarak, which means have a blessed Ramadan.Many of the traditions around Ramadan involve gathering together, community work and charity, which has to be compromised due to social distancing restrictions.The coronavirus pandemic has curbed large gatherings for prayers and public tars, or meals to break the fast.Islams holiest sites in Saudi Arabia and Jerusalem have been largely empty of worshippers as authorities are forced to impose unprecedented restrictions.In a rare occurrence in Islams ,-year history, Meccas Grand Mosque and the Prophets Mosque in Medina - the religions two holiest locations - will be closed to the public during the fasting period.Prayers from inside the mosque at Mecca on the first evening of Ramadan on Thursday were restricted to clerics, security staff and cleaners, in a ceremony broadcast live on television.New guidance released by The Muslim Council of Britain has outlined how Muslims can practise their faith during the holy month while keeping safe from coronavirus.

title: priti patel coronavirus lockdown briefing
story: PRITI Patel today thanked emergency services putting their lives on the line to tackle coronavirus - and told Brits it is imperative to follow lockdown rules.The Home Secretary warned we are not out of danger yet as she thanked Brits for their spirit of national unity.Ms Patel told the No briefing: Staying at home for five weeks has changed the way we live our lives and I know how tough this has been.This countrys efforts are working...you have fostered a spirit of national unity which has helped us get through this time.But we are not out of danger yet.It is imperative that people continue to follow the rules designed to protect their families, their friends and their loved ones.I urge you all to stay strong and embrace that spirit of national unity by continuing to stay at home.We all want toto living our lives as normally as possible and as safely as we can. That is what the government is working towards.”Her plea came after the UK coronavirus death toll today overtook the governments benchmark for doing very well of , deaths.A total of , have now lost their lives to the disease, with  deaths reported in  hours.Despite the grim milestone, Brits have developed lockdown fatigue and are venturing outdoors as temperatures rise.It comes as:When asked about the number, Ms Patel said a great deal of progress has been made - but added we are not out of the woods yet.She also described the milestone as a “deeply tragic and moving moment”.Professor Stephen Powis, head of the NHS, added: , deaths is clearly , too many.The first thing to emphasis, this is not going to be something we will get over in the next few weeks...this is not a sprint this is a marathon.It is still absolutely critical we continue to follow the social distancing guidelines because we are seeing the benefit.He said number of patients with coronavirus in critical care beds in the UK has fallen by  per cent since this time last week - dropping from , to ,.And the number of people in hospital overall with the disease has fallen compared to last week.But Prof Powis still pleaded for people to stay at home during the sunny weather and follow the rules.He warned: I cant emphasise enough that we are far from there yet, its really critical that people maintain their compliance with those social distancing instructions.It wont take much for this virus to start increasing its transmission again and to sp widely, and it would be foolish and not rightwe lost the benefits that we have gained over the last four weeks, which I know have been hard for everybody.So its really important that despite the weather, we stay at home, we keep to the guidelines that weve been issued with.Ms Patel also outlined the work emergency crews have been doing during lockdown - including seizing illegal drugs and arresting domestic abuse suspects.She revealed last week Border Force found £million worth of cocaine set to be smuggled into the UK hidden in boxes of face masks.And she also told how some drivers are using quieter roads “as their own personal race track” - and revealed one reckless motorist was clocked doing mph on the M.Another driver was caught by cops doing mph in a mph zone in London as criminals take advantage of the empty roads.The MP added: Our world class law enforcement is adapting and they are on to you.Five weeks after the severe restrictions were introduced, roads, beaches and parks have started filling up again.At the start of the week less than half the normal traffic was on the roads across Britain.But the number was still up three per cent on the previous week - to  per cent.And the latest Google Maps data shows a rise in the amount of people on the move.Visits to parks and beaches were up  per cent - just one third below their pre-lockdown figure.In the past week, more than  parks and green spaces reopened across the country.And the number visiting recreation locations such as shopping centres was up ten per cent.In first few weeks of lockdown the proportion of people visiting restaurants, shopping centres and galleries dropped by  per cent.But that is now down by just  per cent on its normal level.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Britain entered the coronavirus lockdown on March , and some European nations are beginning to ease measures.But the government is keen to not jump too soon in relaxing the rules in case the UK is hit by a second deadly wave.Britain must first meet five key tests including slashing the number of cases and securing regular supplies of PPE by a deadline of May .Currently the UK rules state that people should not meet up with anyone they do not live with.And people continue to be urged to stay inside and only go out for essentials such as food shopping or daily exercise.Anyone who flouts the new crackdown will face fines of up to £, or even arrest when cops are given emergency powers.Police also now have the power to issue on-the-spot fines of £ for meeting under the new legislation.Those who keep disobeying can be arrested and locked up.There are hopes Britains lockdown rules could be relaxed to allow people to socialise with ten of their closest family and friends.Ministers are reportedly looking at easing strict stay at home rules in favour of creating groups of people known as clusters or bubbles.It is hoped the potential easing would allow close family members to meet for meals, allow couples who do not live together to see each other, and allow friends to share childcare.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: health secretary matt hancock coronavirus clinical trial
story: MATT Hancock has shared a photo of a nurse taking his blood as he takes part in a clinical plasma trial.The Health Secretary joined a study to seethose who have recovered from coronavirus could help , patients a week suffering with the virus.It involves using convalescent plasma transfused into people struggling to beat the disease and produce their own antibodies.This follows on from a treatment used during the SARS outbreak and was given the go-ahead from the Government this week.Mr Hancock posted: The hugely important clinical trial will help our NHS treat #coronavirus patients using plasma.If youre asked, please take part. Its painless.He added: The UK has world-leading le sciences and research sectors and I have every hope this treatment will be a major milestone in our fight against this disease.Hundreds of people are participating in national trials already for potential treatments and the scaling up of convalescent plasma collection means thousands could potentially benefit from it in the future.NHS Blood and Transplant will contact those who have recovered from confirmed Covid- and could be a donor.Blood is taken from an arm, circulated through a machine to separate the plasma and ed to the donor.The -minute process produces two units of plasma, which can be frozen and stored for future use.Dr Gail Mlin, from NHSBT, said: “We are rapidly building our capability to collect plasma so we can quickly move into supplying hospitals at scale, should the trial show patient benefit.”Prof Jonathan Van Tam, Deputy Chief Medical Officer, added that the UK already had more than , people involved testing a range of medicines to tackle Covid-.It comes as:It comes as it was revealed lockdown rules could be eased to allow people to socialise with ten of their closest family and friends.Ministers are reportedly looking at easing strict stay at home rules in favour of creating groups of people known as clusters or bubbles.But Brits will today be warned they could be hit with even stricter lockdown measuresthey continue to flout the rules.Five weeks after the severe restrictions were introduced, roads, beaches and parks have started filling up again.At a news conference, Home Secretary Priti Patel will produce official data that proves rule-breaking is on the increase.Coronavirus deaths in the UK today passed the governments best-case scenario of up to , victims after  more people died in England.The grim milestone was given back in March as a benchmark for Britain doing very well in the pandemic.The grim number means , people have now died in England from Covid- - and pushes the UK deaths to ,.The official UK figures will be released later today by the Department of Health.In March, Professor Stephen Powis, NHS England medical director, gave the grisly best case scenario of up to , deaths as he urged Brits to follow social distancing guidelines.We are backing a proposal by Lord Ashcroft to honour our health heroes with the gallantry gong given for acts of bravery that did not take place in battle.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits lockdown energy usage routine
story: ENERGY usage figures have shown how Brits’ daily routines have changed since the start of the lockdown – from eating their dinner earlier than normal to waking up later.With the nation encouraged to stay home due to the coronavirus pandemic, people are shaking up their routines and using energy at dferent times of the day.The data suggests that with no commute to the office, people are waking up later and there is now a surge in electricity usage being seen at am, compared to am pre-lockdown.Lunchtimes appear to be taking place at around pm and bring a  per cent increase in energy usage, as households combine energy needed to cook food with working from home.The figures from British Gas, using data from more than a million of its smart meter customers, also show dinner time has been brought forward, with an energy spike now taking place at pm compared to between pm and pm previously.Bedtimes are showing to be roughly the same with demand dropping off between pm and midnight, as expected.However, it seems more Brits than ever have become night owls, with some staying up late to watch TV or play video games, with higher electricity use being seen between am and am.Joanna Flowers, British Gas service and repair engineer, said: “The world is a very dferent place compared to this time two months ago. When it comes to energy, we’ve changed how much we use, and when we use it.“There are some simple things people can do around the home to save energy, and to troubleshoot any small problems themselves. This helps minimise demand for home visits, and enables us to prioritise vulnerable customers and emergency response cases.“I can’t bear the thought of anyone going without a hot shower, so we are doing all we can to attend to emergencies while keeping people safe – like wearing protective clothing and asking customers to wait in another room while we get their boiler working.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Using its data, British Gas predicts it will receive more than , breakdown calls in the space of a week.These are likely to consist of boiler breakdowns as well as essential appliances – including washing machines, fridges and cookers.Since lockdown began, thousands of British Gas employees have set up remote call centres in their homes, and have taken nearly , calls from customers looking for support with broken down appliances and help paying their bills.During this time, complying with social distancing guidelines and safety procedures, engineers have been focusing on emergencies and essential visits.They have fixed more than , boilers and , washing machines, ensuring that everyone has heating and hot water, and can clean their clothes.The energy and home services provider has also sent , of its most vulnerable customers pre-loaded prepayment cards totalling more than £million and has helped more than , with their payment plans.Top tips from British Gas on troubleshooting issues around the home, and saving energy where you can:. Manage how much energy you use for everyday tasks. You’ll be able to find lots of ideas online, such as using a cooler setting on the washing machine, and then hanging laundry outside instead of relying on radiators or the tumble drier.. Maximise efficiency in the kitchen. Most of us are cooking more than usual, which is driving up how much energy we use. There are some simple things you can do about this though, like turning the oven off  minutes before your food is ready , and maximising oven time by batch-cooking a few meals at once.. Only use the energy that’s needed. This is an obvious one, but make sure to only heat and light the rooms that are in use. People also often underestimate how much energy is wasted by leaving appliances on standby. Similarly, electronics that are left plugged in once fully charged will continue to use energy. Small changes like these make a big dference to your energy bill. Maximise the heat. Many people won’t be using their heating while the weather is warmer, butyou are, it’s important to make sure your system is working as efficiently as possible. There’s lots of things you can do at home, like bleeding your radiators to keep everything in tip top shape until your next service. Try British Gas Boiler Support on Google Assistant. It can help you to troubleshoot the most common heating and hot water issues and you don’t have to be a British Gas customer to use it. For example,you think there’s a problem with your boiler, you simply say to your Google Home, Google Nest device or Google Assistant app on your smartphone: “OK Google, talk to Boiler Support”. The system will then help you to figure out the issue.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain must go back work
story: NewsBritain ‘must go back to work’ and ‘exit plan is needed,’ warns Philip HammondThe former Conservative Chancellor has said a plan is needed to save the economy as the UK will be “living with Covid-” for a long time. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Ex-Chancellor Philip Hammond has urged the government to publish a coronavirus exit plan as he insists Britons must go back to work to restart the economy.The former Conservative chancellor has insisted a plan to allow the economy to escape the lockdown must be published next week, because the country will be “living with Covid” for a long time. He said the government cannot wait until a vaccine has been developed, in an interview on BBC Radio ’s Today programme. “The reality is that we have to start reopening the economy. But we have to do it living with Covid,” he said. “We canapost wait until a vaccine is developed, produced in sufficient quantity and rolled out across the population. The economy wonapost survive that long.” Mr Hammond said the strategy so far of “locking everything down and keeping everything locked down is relatively straightforward”. “The challenge of how to carefully, progressively, methodically reopen, protecting both health and jobs, is much, much more challenging and calls for a really skilful political leadership,” he continued. Answering whether he thinks this should be published soon, he said he hopes the Prime Minister’swill signal change. The comments coming after widespread criticism of the government for refusing to even discuss a plan. The Scottish and Welsh governments have publicly discussed detailed options. Brits could be allowed to meet up with  of their closest family or friends under one idea to relax the coronavirus lockdown, it was revealed today.  It is understood that the UK government is considering letting people socialise outside of their households in small bubbles as it plans an exit strategy. The move would widen the current stay at home advice to include meals and other social activities with close relatives and friends. It would also mean couples who do not live together can spend time together. However, people would only be able to nominate one or two households to be part of their cluster” and would not be able to mingle with anyone .  The idea is also being considered by the UK Government, Mail Online  reports. A Whitehall source told the paper: If we can find a way to allow a bit more flexibility without risking transmission of the disease running higher then we will do it.

title: coronavirus dominic cummings involved secretive
story: NewsCoronavirus: Dominic Cummings attended meetings of science  advising UK governmentThe government faces "signicant questions" after it was revealed Dominic Cummings, Boris Johnsons chief adviser, attended a key meeting of the Scientic Advisory Group for EmergenciesShareCommentsByGavin CordonAnna MacSwan:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsCummings was on a leaked list of Sage attendees " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Dominic Cummings, the Prime Ministeraposs chief adviser, has been taking part in meetings held by the secretive scientic group which advises ministers on coronavirus. Mr Cummings was one of  attendees at a key meeting of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencieson March , the day Boris Johnson announced the nationwide lockdown, according to a list leaked to the . Ben Warner, a data scientist who worked on the Vote Leave campaign during the Brexit referendum, is also understood to have been present.The revelation yesterday evening has raised signicant questions about the independence of the scientic advice given by Sage. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here A former government chief scientic adviser, Sir David King, said he was shocked to find that there were political advisers involved. If you are giving science advice, your advice should be free of any political bias. That is just so critically important, he told the . A No spokesman confirmed Mr Cummings had attended Sage meetings but denied he was a member of the group. Sage provides independent scientic advice to the Government. Political advisers have no role in this, they said. The scientists on Sage are among the most eminent in their fields. It is factually wrong and damaging to sensible public debate to imply their advice is affected by government advisers listening to discussions. Downing Street say that Mr Cummings had attended some Sage meetings and listened to some meetings now they are all virtual. He and another adviser do this in order to understand better the scientic debates concerning this emergency and also to understand better the limits of how science and data can help government decisions, the spokesman added. Occasionally they ask questions or offer help when scientists mention problems in Whitehall.  The Government is under increasing pressure to reveal who sits on Sage given its critical role giving advice on how to tackle the coronavirus crisis. It has never released a list of the aposs members of attendees, although iniduals are free to disclose they are part of the group. In a letter to Parliament earlier this month, Sir Patrick Vallance, the UKaposs chief scientic adviser and chair of Sage, said the group does not disclose its membership on the advice of the Centre for the Protection of National Infrastructure . He said this is for security reasons, and to protect members from lobbying and other forms of unwanted influence. Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth said the disclosure that Mr Cummings had been attending Sage raised signicant questions about the credibility of Government decision-making. Dominic Cummings has no place on the Governmentaposs scientic advisory group on the coronavirus, he said. He is a political adviser, not a medical or scientic expert. If the public are to have confidence in the Sage, the Government must make clear Dominic Cummings can no longer participate or attend.

The move would widen the current stay at home advice to include meals and other social activities with close relatives and friends. It would also mean couples who do not live together can spend time together. However, people would only be able to nominate one or two households to be part of their cluster, and would not be able to mingle with anyone . For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here It comes after Nicola Sturgeon today said the Scottish government is looking at the proposal as one possible way to relax restrictions. But the First Minister warnedthe idea does happen, itaposs got to be the same people day-to-day, week-to-week to prevent Covid- being passed on more widely. The idea is also being considered by the UK Government, Mail Online reports. A Whitehall source told the paper: If we can find a way to allow a bit more flexibility without risking transmission of the disease running higher then we will do it. Similar plans are also being considered in Belgium. Scotlandaposs government has gone further than UK officials in laying out how lockdown might eventually be eased. Yesterday Ms Sturgeon published a -page document saying outdoor activities might resume, and businesses may reopenthey can keep customers and staff  metres apart. The First Minister also suggested schools could reopen with modications needed in some classrooms. Health Secretary Matt Hancock has refused to comment in detail on the plan for the whole of the UK. But today he said Ms Sturgeonaposs plan was essentially a reiteration of his own five tests of when lockdown can be relaxed. What weaposre trying to do is to do is, how do we get a semblance of normality back into our lives because the lockdown - it is essential that people stick with it just now - but itaposs having consequences of its own. More than , people have now signed a petition set up by the National Education Union which asks the government not to reopen them before itaposs safe and to commit to testing and tracing to help that.The new general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women TeachersDr Patrick Roach, warned that staff concerns must be fully addressed before teachers would be willing to come back.In a letter to Education Secretary Gavin Williamson earlier this week, Dr Roach demanded personal protective equipmentfor all staff, anti-viral cleaning measures and guidelines on how social distancing would be enforced in schools. Will they look dferent when they     On Thursday Nicola Sturgeon talked about “rearranging classrooms” so that the m distancing could be observed.The First Minister said alternating weeks for pupils was the type of option her government is considering whenever lockdown is eased. She also raised the prospect of redesigning classrooms as a way of enforcing social distancing. She has consistently been more open with the public about measures to deal with coronavirus suggesting the Westminster government will be having similar discussions.Sturgeon said of schools: “I think some countries have perhaps had some children in school go back.“There has been some talk, and it is certainly an option that has to be considered, although we might not do it, some kids go one week, other kids go the next week, so that there’s the ability to have smaller classes. “These are the kind of options we are dealing with.” The Welsh First Minister has also stipulated that the m rule must be observed in schools currently and in the future.For many schools that may inevitably mean a new layout for classroom and for teachers to handle fewer pupils at a time.The details have not yet been decided but they are part of the discussion which will have to happen before schools .    They want to - or certainly their unions want them to have that option.The unions representing support staff have banded together to demand their members have the right equipment before theyto work.The GMB, Unison and Unite have issued a joint statement asking the government to engage with them ahead of anyto school. They say their members need proper equipment and that staff are currently very worried. At the moment PPE provision is patchy.One school told the Mirror they have equipment to be worn when dealing with an ill child but not for other situations.But with many children potentially posing as carriers rather than suffering from the virus there are concerns that staff could be more at risk than the children they care for.Andy Prendergast, Senior Organiser for the GMB, told the Mirror: “There’s a huge number of hurdles we need to get over before schools can be open across the board. There’s the problems with PPE which are problems everywhere and at the moment we can’t get enough into hospitals and care homes so the idea that there’s tonnes of it waiting for schools is quite simply not the case.  “The relatively small number of schools that are open are struggling to get PPE, but the idea that we can open all the schools in the country and have them work safely just doesn’t work.“One of the big issues that they’ve got is lack of hand sanitiser and some of the advice being given is that people can go and wash their hands. The obvious problem with that isyou’re in a class with a load of kids and you have to go and wash your hands. That involves you having to go somewhere, having to touch numerous doors, wash your hands, go all the way back and what do the kids do in the meantime “What we’re saying very clearly is we need to have adequate risk assessments and there needs to be adequate stocks of PPE to protect the members as we move forward on that.“While there are national shortages of PPE we can’t see that happening any time soon but obviously we want to get people back to usual but to do that we need to be satisfied that members - and also the kids and their families - are going to be protected.”“We’ve had at least one member who works in a school who has died of covid- and, while we can’t say for absolute certain how they got the virus, we are extremely concerned that that may have been spread through the school. At the moment the they’re not being forced back to work and the government lockdown continues for the next few weeks but the concern is what happens after that.Will teachers be tested  If they show symptoms anyone who works in a school will be eligible for a test as a key worker as part of the announcement by Health Secretary Matt Hancock of the extension of the governmentaposs testing programme. They need to sign up or be referred by their manager on gov.ukThe newly-unveiled system has suffered teething problems as the government struggled to cope with demand. Some , of the test at home kits were ordered within two minutes of an online portal opening for million key workers and their families. A further , testing slots at drive-through testing sites were taken on Friday - forcing the government to close the entire self-testing website for the day.But it is expected to be back up and running from am on Saturday. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailShoppers flocked to DIY stores including Homebase and BQ this morning, with crazy long queues pictured up and down the country. DIY giant BQ reopened more than  stores this weekend, despite the majority of high street chains keeping their doors shut. BQ has been closed since the end of March although customers have been able to use click and collect services to purchase goods. Hardware stores have been classed as ‘essential’ during the coronavirus crisis, but some fear more stores reopening may cause people to flout lockdown restrictions and go on non-essential journeys. One carer from York said she had “never seen anything like it” after visiting her local branch to pick up new light bulbs for a -year-old lady she looks after. She said she saw shoppers leaving the stores with barbecues and gardening items. Tracey Sharp, , told Yorkshire Live: The queues have been round the car park. Itaposs just crazy. Iaposve never seen anything like it. I go past every single day and itaposs just packed whatever time of the day.Yesterday it was all round the car park. That was at am and again at am. A video filmed by Tracey at am today shows the extent of queues outside the store in Hull Road. Itaposs not quite as bad as yesterday, but people are still going crazy because itaposs gardening season and the weather is nice, she said.Iaposve been here  minutes, but I reckon it will take me an hour and a half to get in. There are about  people here. The queue is just getting longer and longer. Not all sections of BQ stores have fully reopened including kitchen and bathroom design, paint mixing and timber and key cutting. The chain has introduced a number of changes to help shoppers adhere to social distancing guidelines, which includes limiting the number of customers in the stores at any one time and installing screens at checkouts.  However Health Secretary Matt Hancock said hardware stores such as BQ were “never required to close in the first place”. He welcomed the move and said it was fine as long as they could stick to social distancing guidelines. He told Sky News: The things that are restarting are things that we never required to close in the first place, but what the companies have been doing is working out how they can have safe working following the social distancing rules whilst people are at work.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Kent couple caught sleeping in the car on a “mini break” to Cornwall have been slapped with a penalty notice and had their car seized. A police officer caught the couple flouting lockdown restrictions on a patrol – and they were found to be driving without insurance and a driving licence.The car was seized by Devon and Cornwall Police and the tourists were issued with two fixed penalty notices, reports Cornwall Live. Police were given powers at the end of March to issue fines to those caught flouting stay-at-home rules. People can end up in courtthe fines are unpaid.  The measures were put in place to limit the spread of coronavirus and make sure people only take essential journeys. The probation PC, who tweets as The Hungry Copper, took to Twitter to share the incident.The tweet read: “Found  people sleeping in a car in #Falmouth Checked their details  both live in #Kent  had driven down for a mini break. But driver had No Insurance  No Driving Licence! Car seized   #FixedPenaltyNotices issued for Breaching the #Covid_ #lockdown #restrictions #StayHome” People have been quick to praise the officer online. One user said: “Absolutely remarkable! Selfishness at its worst and policing at its best. Keep up the good work.” Another said: “Well done for finding these irresponsible idiots. Hope they enjoyed the long walk home.” Others questioned how the couple would be able to make it home without a car, thoughthey had no licence it would be illegal for them to drive home. Another added: “Great these people should be stopped! A mini break are they for real  What happens to them now though  Where do they stay ” This is the latest in a string of incidents, which have seen Brits flout lockdown restrictions.Over the Easter weekend more than  people were fined – which includes one person who drove hundreds of miles to collect an eBay purchase.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA dad who was on a ventilator for  days while he battled COVID- has described coronavirus like breathing through a straw.Robbie Purdie, , spent more than two weeks in intensive care at Dumfries Infirmary, the Daily Record reports.The retired teacher, who is now back at home with we Fiona and children Euan, , and -year-old Caitlin, said it is only thanks to hospital staff that he is still alive. Robbie was working as a supply teacher when he tested positive for COVID- on March . He said: “I’d had a bit of a cough but I became cold and shivery so went home from work.“I suspected it might have been coronavirus so Fiona went to pick up our son from university and our family went into self-isolation for two weeks. “I had horrendous headaches and felt absolutely shattered.“By March , it felt like I was trying to breathe through a straw. My we kept insisting we call for help but I was holding off. “She eventually phoned  and an ambulance was sent for me. I had tests and X-rays at DGRI and was diagnosed with viral pneumonia.” Robbieaposs condition was so bad that medics sedated him before putting him on a ventilator. He added: “I obviously didn’t know what was going on but my we, kids, family and friends had to live through it. “The staff kept Fiona fully informed and nurses and consultants called her frequently to let her know what was going on. “They even sent the family video clips of me when I was unable to contact them myself, which was a real comfort to them.” After improving enough to be taken off the ventilator on April , Robbie could only walk three feet using a zimmer frame and was so weak he could barely speak or write.  But after being discharged home last Monday, he is slowly building up his strength again. Robbie, from Dumfries, said: “It was wonderful to get home. I received the best care in hospital and there’s no doubt the staff saved my le. There was always somebody constantly with me. “Every single member of staff at DGRI was nothing less than utterly professional in every way and all cared for me asI was a relative. “My family and I can never thank them enough for pulling me through this awful illness and getting me back home to my family. “I want to pay tribute to those who planned my course of treatment, delivered it and saw me through the other side. “It’s strange though: because they were obviously wearing gowns and face masks,I walked past them in the street, I wouldn’t recognise them to thank them.

story: NewsExpert shares list of essential medical supplies every home should haveSultan “Sid” Dajani, former treasurer of the Royal Pharmaceutical Society, tells what you need at home from first aid kits to potionsShareCommentsByPunteha van Terheyden:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsKeep your medicine cabinet well organised so you can easily see any important  over-the-counter or prescription drugs " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMany of us have given our homes a spring clean in recent weeks, purged our sock ­drawers and spice racks – but the medicine cabinet ­rarely gets a look-in. Most of us only ever think about it when we’ve sliced open a finger or our head is ­pounding but it’s ­important to declutter medical supplies each year. An annual ­review of ­prescriptions, over-the-counter ­medicines and bits and pieces such as plasters will make sure you’re fully equipped – and could even save your le. Using an old product won’t necessarily land you in hospital, but it won’t work effectively, either. Where you keep your pills and potions matters, too. Here, Sultan “Sid” Dajani, community ­pharmacist and former treasurer of the Royal Pharmaceutical Society, reveals what you need at home and how to store it safely. First aid Everyone needs a decent first aid kit, separate from the medicine cabinet. It should include plasters, bandages, antiseptic wipes to clean wounds and eye wash solution to remove dirt or grit. It needs sterile dressings for when you need to sort a wound at home or on the way to hospital, as well as medical tape to help hold it in place. A thermometer and tweezers for splinters are also a wise choice.  If you use anything, replace it as soon as possible to keep your kit well-stocked. It is also a good idea to have a separate, smaller, first-aid kit in your car for any emergencies as well. Always keep your medication in its packet. The box will feature the directions for use, exactly what is inside and the expiry dates. Sometimes, blister packs are too small for expiration dates, making the packets vital for safety. Medications that are not stored properly or safely will go out of date faster soyou are in any doubt, put it in a pile – somewhere safe, where children cannot get hold of it – to take to the pharmacy, where it can be safely binned. Location Where you keep your cabinet or box is crucial – and bathrooms are not the smartest choice. If it is too warm or humid, then you’ve got a problem. Kitchen cupboards, a utility room with a tumble dryer, on top of the fridge or in direct sunlight are also no-nos. Steam and hot water can get through plastic, even in a packet or box, and medication affected by humidity or heat can become useless. Either that or it can turn more potent and even toxic. It can also put the lives of your family at risk for instance, asthma or epilepsy medication that no longer works or slow-release medication that speeds up and gives you an overdose.  The best place to keep your medication is actually on top of a bedroom wardrobe or shelf in the lounge – preferably in a locked box, out of reach from children. Tell-tale signs your medicine has been affected include capsules sticking together orthey look dferent from each other because colours have run. Checktablets have gone sticky and slimy, or powdery. Also look for any liquids that have leaked. These items should be disposed of. Good to know: Out-of-date aspirin smells like vinegar. Basics If the rush for paracetamol and Calpol has taught us anything, it is to stock up on the basics. These include over-the-counter painkillers for adults and kids, plasters, antihistamine tablets and creams – great for allergies, hay fever, insect bites and nettle stings – medication for heartburn and anti-diarrhoea and rehydration salts.  You never plan to have food poisoning from a dodgy takeaway and you do not want to be caught short. But having too much of any medication is a waste of money as it will probably go off before you can use it all. It is wise to have ViraSoothe or anaesthetic creams as they work faster on stings and bites compared to antihistamine tablets. The cream is good for cuts before you dress them. Some people keep sleeping tablets on standby too, but they may leave you feeling drowsy the next day. Dragonfly CBD oil is non-drowsy and effective. Use-by dates Check every item’s expiry date once a year and remove anything that is out of date as it may not work. It is also important to dispose of any medication that is not in its original packet. While you may know what they are, others might not and take the wrong thing – or wrong dose – by mistake. DONaposT throw these products in the bin, wash them down the sink or flush them away as they can get in to the water supply.  Take them to a pharmacy in a sealed bag to dispose of responsibly. Or, while sticking to social-distancing rules, package old medicines into small bags and post them through the pharmacy’s letter box with a note attached on each that says it is old medication. Get Organised Keep your medicine cabinet well organised so you can easily see any important  over-the-counter or prescription drugs you will soon need more of.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email As the national lockdown enters its fth week, Britons have been warned to continue following the rules in a bid to stop the spread of coronavirus.With forecasters predicting high temperatures throughout the weekend, people are being urged not to defy the rules. The government guidelines are very clear - stay home and stay safe and protect the NHS. People should only be going out for the essentials, for one form of exercise a day and for workthey cannot work from home. But police forces across the UK have found some breaching lockdown rules for frivolous and infuriating reasons. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here  Driving  miles to get a burger In Normanton, Derby, a group of four men from Burton in Staffordshire were caught by police making a -mile round trip to collect a takeaway burger. The men had travelled from the town and were caught by police on Monday, Derbyshire Live report. The men were fined £ each for breaching lockdown rules as police declared the incident an example of unnecessary travel. SkateboardingPolice in Barnsley, South Yorkshire, took to Twitter to urge skateboarders to stop using skate parks.In a series of tweets, neighbourhood officers responsible for community policing in that area, said: Skateboard England, the governing body for skateboarding in England and Wales, has a statement on their homepage that confirms all skateparks are closed and should not be used.  Our officers in Barnsley West neighbourhood team are aware that concerns have been raised about the use of the skate park at Dearne Valley Park, on Pontefract Road. If you are a skateboarder or you have family members who skateboard and would normally go to skate parks, please ensure they are aware of the Government guidance and that they do not attend the local skate park. Beach parties In Wales, police are increasing patrols around the Llanelli beach and North Dock area after a group of  to  teenagers were found having a beach party. The group was found to be underage drinking during the gathering. Collecting a bonsai tree Sussex Police also shared some of the more frivolous reasons people had been flouting lockdown rules. These included driving from Essex to Chichester to collect a bonsai tree, driving from London to take photos of the stars at Beachy Head and visiting a friend who is in self-isolation because of coronavirus symptoms. In a statement, Temporary Chief Inspector Simon Burroughs said: “Please take a moment to think about the impact your actions during the coronavirus crisis are having on public health.” Taking a selfie Earlier this week, a couple were caught breaching lockdown rules by driving  miles to take a selfie at a well-known Staffordshire beauty spot.The couple were seen taking a  picture at The Roaches, a rocky ridge near Tittesworth Reservoir, Staffordshire, having travelled more than  miles from Nottingham.When approached by officers, the couple admitted their mistake and police reminded them of the rules about travelling during the lockdown but did not hand them a fine.  Cutting police tape for a picnic In South Derbyshire, a group cut through police tape which was sealing off a reservoir, in order to have a picnic. PCSO Jamie Gutberlet, who was part of the patrol team who made the discovery, said: During patrols across rural areas we found a number of vehicles parked up a lot of them were not local. We were also quite disappointed that people had ignored the closure of Foremark Reservoir, breaking through the tape to enter. ‘Lockdown’ party Earlier this month, a -year-old woman was arrested in Glasgow for hosting a “lockdown party,” The Glasgow Times reported. A force spokesperson said: “Officers attended a property on Montford Avenue in Glasgow shortly after .pm on Sunday, April  following a report of a disturbance. “A woman, , was arrested in connection with the incident. “Additionally, two men were issued with warnings.”  Bolt cutters used to enter park Bolt cutters were used to cut chains around the entrance to the tennis courts and outdoor gym at in Uttoxeter. The chains had been put in place to stop people being tempted to play in the area during lockdown.A spokesman for  East Staffordshire Borough Council  told Derbyshire Live they were disappointed to see the chains had been cut.Sunshine kickabout A group in Corby, Northamptonshire, were filmed playing football yesterday evening, according to the Northamptonshire . Police eventually arrived to break up the party after local residents had tried their best to get the men to go home.

She was one of four neighbours from Cumbria who scooped a share of £k playing People’s Postcode Lottery. And the surprise windfall, delivered on the  March, came on the very day she was due to welcome her two new bundles of joy into the world. Thrilled Caroline said: This year, we’ve been very lucky, it’s amazing. It’s also quite weird how our prize arrived on our twins’ original due date. I think we’ll use the money first to go on holiday, maybe two, somewhere like the Canaries so not too far for the kids.  I’m so happy we started playing People’s Postcode Lottery a few years ago. It’s a mix of a feel-good factor knowing you’re helping charities by playing and that there’s a chance of winning yourself – it’s double awesome!
